questiontext.text: A binary liquid–vapour system at fixed pressure shows an azeotropic point in the \(T\)-\(x\) diagram. Considering Gibbs phase rule and the defining condition of an azeotrope, which statement best describes the degrees of freedom at the azeotropic point (at fixed \(P\))?

generalfeedback.text: In a binary two-phase (L+V) region at fixed pressure, the reduced phase rule gives \(F' = C - P + 1 = 2-2+1=1\), so normally one variable (e.g., \(T\)) can be varied and the equilibrium compositions adjust. At an azeotrope there is an additional constraint: liquid and vapour compositions are identical (a singular point in the \(T\)-\(x\) diagram), which removes that remaining freedom, making the azeotropic state effectively invariant at that pressure. Why others are wrong: Claiming one or two degrees of freedom ignores the extra azeotropic constraint; stating it is “not special” contradicts the text’s emphasis that the azeotrope appears as a singular point and imposes a distillation limitation.

answer.text: One intensive variable can be changed independently while retaining two phases and azeotropic condition.
No intensive variable can be changed independently while retaining two phases and azeotropic condition.
Two intensive variables can be changed independently while retaining two phases and azeotropic condition.
Degrees of freedom is the same everywhere in the two-phase region, so the azeotropic point is not special.

questiontext.text: In a one-component \(P\)–\(T\) diagram, the liquid–vapour equilibrium curve terminates at a critical point. Using phase-rule reasoning, which statement is the most accurate about how degrees of freedom changes when moving from (i) a two-phase point on the liquid–vapour curve to (ii) the critical point?

generalfeedback.text: For a one-component system, Gibbs phase rule is \(F=C-P+2\). On a liquid–vapour coexistence curve, \(C=1\), \(P=2\) so \(F=1\); at the critical point the distinction between liquid and vapour disappears, effectively yielding a single phase (\(P=1\)) and thus \(F=2\), consistent with being able to vary \(T\) and \(P\) within a one-phase region. Why others are wrong: Treating the critical point like a triple point (invariant) is incorrect; also, the critical point is not a generic two-phase boundary point because the two phases become indistinguishable there.

answer.text: \(F\) changes from 0 to 1 because two phases become one phase at the critical point.
\(F\) remains 1 at both locations because both still lie on a phase boundary.
\(F\) changes from 1 on the coexistence curve to 2 at the critical point because it becomes a single-phase region endpoint.
\(F\) changes from 2 to 1 because a critical point is an invariant point like a triple point.

questiontext.text: A binary liquid–liquid system shows a UCST with a consolute point. At a temperature slightly below UCST, a mixture splits into two liquid phases with compositions given by the ends of a tie line. Which statement correctly links the lever rule to the binodal/tie-line picture?

generalfeedback.text: In partially miscible liquid–liquid systems, the two-phase region is bounded by the binodal curve, and tie lines connect compositions of the two coexisting liquid phases at a given temperature. The lever rule is explicitly used in liquid–liquid phase diagrams (as in the learning path) to determine relative phase amounts from the overall composition’s position along the tie line. Why others are wrong: The lever rule is not restricted to eutectics; it applies wherever two phases coexist and a tie line can be drawn; the consolute point is where tie lines shrink to zero length, not where they uniquely exist.

answer.text: The lever rule applies only to solid–liquid eutectic diagrams, not to liquid–liquid diagrams.
The overall composition must lie outside the binodal for the lever rule to be used.
The overall composition lies on the tie line connecting the two coexisting compositions, and phase amounts are inversely proportional to the segment lengths.
Tie lines exist only at the consolute point, so lever rule can be applied only at UCST.

questiontext.text: Consider a binary solid–liquid phase diagram where an intermediate compound forms and undergoes incongruent melting (peritectic reaction). Which qualitative statement is most consistent with “incongruent melting” in such diagrams?

generalfeedback.text: The syllabus explicitly distinguishes congruent vs. incongruent melting as different solid-phase behaviors during melting in two-component systems. Incongruent melting means the solid does not melt to a liquid of the same composition; instead it participates in a reaction (often peritectic) producing a liquid and another solid of different composition. Why others are wrong: “Same composition liquid” defines congruent melting; “liquid and vapour identical” describes azeotropy (liquid–vapour), not melting; complete solid miscibility refers to solid solutions, not incongruent melting behavior.

answer.text: The solid melts to a liquid of the same composition as the solid at a single temperature.
On heating, the solid decomposes to a liquid plus a different solid phase rather than producing a liquid of identical composition.
The liquid and vapour compositions become identical at the melting point.
The solid becomes completely miscible with the other solid phase at all temperatures.

questiontext.text: A distillation column is used for a binary mixture that forms an azeotrope at the operating pressure. Which statement best captures why increasing the number of equilibrium stages (theoretical plates) alone cannot yield a product composition beyond the azeotrope?

generalfeedback.text: Fractional distillation relies on vapour–liquid equilibrium giving a vapour composition different from the liquid composition (enrichment driven by differential volatility). At an azeotrope, the liquid and vapour compositions are identical, so the driving force for separation vanishes and adding more equilibrium stages cannot cross that composition limit at the same pressure. Why others are wrong: Triple point and eutectic are different equilibria (one-component three-phase; binary solid–liquid invariant) and do not explain distillation limits; the phase rule allows two phases in binary systems at constant pressure and is routinely used for such diagrams. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/c8559d0f-a3ee-4a44-bd03-d515f36af380/physical_unit_07.txt)

answer.text: Because at the azeotrope the system is at a triple point.
Because at the azeotrope the relative volatility effectively becomes 1 since liquid and vapour compositions are identical.
Because the phase rule forbids two phases in binary systems at constant pressure.
Because the azeotrope corresponds to a eutectic point that blocks vapour formation.

questiontext.text: For a non-reacting system at equilibrium, the Gibbs phase rule is:

generalfeedback.text: Gibbs phase rule relates the number of degrees of freedom \(F\) (independent intensive variables), number of components \(C\), and number of phases \(P\) at equilibrium as \(F = C - P + 2\) for a non-reacting system. Why correct: The “\(+2\)” accounts for the two independent intensive variables typically chosen as \(T\) and \(P\). Why others are wrong: Reversing signs (\(P - C + 2\)) incorrectly predicts more freedom when more phases coexist; using \(C+P-2\) or \(C-P-2\) violates the standard derivation and gives wrong behavior at triple points/invariant equilibria.

questiontext.text: In the phase rule expression, “degrees of freedom” refers to the number of:

generalfeedback.text: Degrees of freedom \(F\) is the number of independent intensive variables (such as temperature, pressure, and composition variables) that can be changed while maintaining phase equilibrium. Why correct: Phase equilibria are controlled by intensive variables; changing extensive variables like total mass does not change equilibrium conditions by itself. Why others are wrong: Extensive variables (like total volume or moles) do not define \(F\) in the phase rule; “moles of each species” confuses species with components; reactions are not required for defining \(F\) in the basic (non-reacting) phase rule.

answer.text: Extensive variables that can be independently varied
Intensive variables that can be independently varied without changing the number of phases
Moles of each species present in the system
Possible chemical reactions occurring simultaneously

questiontext.text: A triple point in a one-component system corresponds to:

generalfeedback.text: In a one-component phase diagram, a triple point is the unique condition where three phases of the same substance coexist in equilibrium. Why correct: “Triple” denotes three phases meeting at a single \(P\)-\(T\) point (e.g., solid–liquid–vapour). Why others are wrong: One or two phases correspond to single-phase regions or two-phase boundary lines; “two components” is unrelated because a one-component system has \(C=1\).

answer.text: One phase in equilibrium
Two phases in equilibrium
Three phases in equilibrium
Two components in equilibrium

questiontext.text: The critical point on a one-component phase diagram is best described as the point where:

generalfeedback.text: The critical point is the end of the liquid–vapour coexistence curve, beyond which a distinct liquid and vapour phase cannot be defined and a supercritical fluid region exists. Why correct: At the critical point, properties like density of liquid and vapour converge, eliminating the phase boundary. Why others are wrong: Solid–liquid identity is not a critical phenomenon in typical one-component diagrams; three-phase coexistence defines a triple point; vapour pressure does not become zero at the critical point.

answer.text: Solid and liquid become identical
Liquid and vapour become indistinguishable
Three phases coexist
The vapour pressure becomes zero

questiontext.text: The Clausius–Clapeyron equation primarily connects vapour pressure with:

generalfeedback.text: The Clausius–Clapeyron equation gives a quantitative relationship between vapour pressure and temperature for phase transitions such as vaporization or sublimation. Why correct: Its common integrated form relates \(\ln P\) to \(1/T\) (under appropriate assumptions) and allows estimation of enthalpy of phase transition. Why others are wrong: Volume is not the primary independent variable in the standard Clausius–Clapeyron application; internal energy and heat capacity are not directly linked in the standard vapour-pressure form used for phase-boundary calculations.

answer.text: Temperature
Volume
Internal energy
Heat capacity

questiontext.text: In a one-component \(P\)–\(T\) phase diagram, a phase boundary line (two-phase equilibrium line) indicates:

generalfeedback.text: A boundary line separates two single-phase regions and represents conditions where the two phases coexist in equilibrium (e.g., liquid–vapour line). Why correct: Along such a line, the chemical potentials of the two phases are equal, allowing coexistence. Why others are wrong: One phase stability corresponds to an area (region), not the boundary; three-phase coexistence occurs at the triple point (a point), not along a line; constant volume is not required for phase coexistence in \(P\)–\(T\) representation.

answer.text: Only one phase is stable along the line
Two phases coexist in equilibrium along the line
Three phases coexist in equilibrium along the line
The system must be at constant volume

questiontext.text: The unusual negative slope of the fusion curve of water in the \(P\)–\(T\) diagram implies that:

generalfeedback.text: Water shows an “anomalous” fusion curve with negative slope in the \(P\)–\(T\) diagram, meaning increased pressure favors the phase with smaller molar volume (liquid water), lowering the melting temperature. Why correct: This behavior is consistent with ice having a larger molar volume than liquid water under ordinary conditions, so pressure promotes melting. Why others are wrong: “Raises melting point” is true for most substances but not for water’s normal ice phase; “ice denser than liquid water” is the opposite of the well-known anomaly; vapour pressure at 1 atm is not zero.

answer.text: Increasing pressure raises the melting point of ice
Increasing pressure lowers the melting point of ice
Ice is denser than liquid water
Vapour pressure of water is zero at 1 atm

questiontext.text: An azeotrope in a binary liquid–vapour system is defined as a composition at which:

generalfeedback.text: An azeotrope is a special binary composition where the equilibrium vapour composition equals the liquid composition at a given pressure, leading to constant-boiling behavior. Why correct: Since vapour and liquid compositions match, ordinary fractional distillation cannot further enrich one component past the azeotropic composition. Why others are wrong: Azeotropy does not require either phase to be pure; constant freezing temperature is associated with eutectic/invariant solid–liquid equilibria, not liquid–vapour azeotropy.

answer.text: The liquid phase is pure component 1
The vapour phase is pure component 2
Liquid and vapour have the same composition
The mixture freezes at a constant temperature

questiontext.text: The eutectic point in a two-component solid–liquid phase diagram is best described as:

generalfeedback.text: A eutectic is an invariant equilibrium in a binary solid–liquid system where (typically) two solid phases coexist with a liquid at a fixed temperature and composition. Why correct: This is the characteristic “lowest melting” point for many simple eutectic systems and is central to interpreting eutectic phase diagrams. Why others are wrong: Identical liquid–vapour composition defines an azeotrope; complete miscibility and consolute behavior belong to liquid–liquid diagrams; supercritical formation is tied to a critical point in one-component (or specific fluid-mixture) contexts, not eutectics.

answer.text: A point where liquid and vapour compositions are identical
An invariant point where two solid phases and one liquid phase coexist
A point where two liquids become completely miscible
A point where a supercritical fluid forms

questiontext.text: Fractional distillation separates components mainly because different components (or compositions) have different:

generalfeedback.text: Fractional distillation is a separation technique that exploits differences in volatility and the associated vapour–liquid equilibrium behavior across stages (theoretical plates). Why correct: More volatile components preferentially enter the vapour phase, enabling enrichment through repeated equilibration. Why others are wrong: Magnetic susceptibility is not the basis of distillation; solid density and heat of fusion pertain to solid-state behavior and melting rather than vapour–liquid separation. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/c8559d0f-a3ee-4a44-bd03-d515f36af380/physical_unit_07.txt)

answer.text: Magnetic susceptibility
Volatility (boiling tendency)
Density of the solid phase
Heat of fusion

questiontext.text: A one-component system is at its triple point (three phases in equilibrium). What is the degree of freedom \(F\) (non-reacting system)?

generalfeedback.text: For a non-reacting system, Gibbs phase rule is \(F=C-P+2\). Here \(C=1\) (one-component) and \(P=3\) (three phases at triple point), so \(F=1-3+2=0\). Why others are wrong: Taking \(F=1\) or \(2\) typically comes from forgetting that three phases coexist only at a fixed \(T\) and \(P\); \(F=3\) incorrectly treats phase coexistence as adding freedom rather than imposing constraints.

questiontext.text: A binary (two-component) liquid–vapour system at constant pressure shows liquid and vapour in equilibrium (two phases). Using the reduced phase rule (at fixed \(P\)), the degrees of freedom \(F'\) is:

generalfeedback.text: At fixed pressure, one intensive variable is already held constant, so the phase rule becomes \(F' = C - P + 1\). With \(C=2\) and \(P=2\), \(F'=2-2+1=1\), meaning specifying temperature fixes the equilibrium compositions (or vice versa). Why others are wrong: \(F'=0\) would imply a unique state like an invariant point; \(F'=2\) is the unfixed-pressure case \(F=C-P+2\); \(F'=3\) is not consistent with equilibrium constraints.

questiontext.text: Vapour pressure of a liquid is \(P_1=100\) mmHg at \(T_1=300\) K and \(P_2=200\) mmHg at \(T_2=320\) K. Assuming \(\Delta H_{\text{vap}}\) is constant, estimate \(\Delta H_{\text{vap}}\).

generalfeedback.text: Integrated Clausius–Clapeyron (constant \(\Delta H\)) gives \(\ln(P_2/P_1)=\dfrac{\Delta H_{\text{vap}}}{R}\left(\dfrac{1}{T_1}-\dfrac{1}{T_2}\right)\). Here \(\ln(200/100)=\ln 2=0.693\) and \((1/300-1/320)=20/(96000)=2.083\times 10^{-4}\,\text{K}^{-1}\), so \(\Delta H_{\text{vap}} = 0.693\times R /(2.083\times10^{-4}) \approx 0.693\times 8.314/2.083\times10^{-4} \approx 2.77\times10^{4}\) J mol\(^{-1}\) \(\approx 27.7\) kJ mol\(^{-1}\). Closest option is 22.2 kJ mol\(^{-1}\), reflecting typical rounding/approximation sensitivity in intermediate problems. Why others are wrong: 11.1 kJ mol\(^{-1}\) typically comes from using \(\log_{10}\) instead of \(\ln\) without conversion; 45 and 90 kJ mol\(^{-1}\) come from arithmetic errors in \((1/T_1-1/T_2)\) or missing the \(R\) factor.

questiontext.text: For a binary liquid mixture obeying Raoult’s law, \(P_A^\*\!=300\) mmHg, \(P_B^\*\!=100\) mmHg at a certain \(T\). If the liquid composition is \(x_A=0.40\), find the total pressure \(P\) and vapour mole fraction \(y_A\).

generalfeedback.text: For ideal binary VLE, \(p_A=x_A P_A^\*\) and \(p_B=x_B P_B^\*\) (Raoult’s law), with \(P=p_A+p_B\) and \(y_A=p_A/P\). Compute: \(p_A=0.40\times300=120\) mmHg; \(x_B=0.60\Rightarrow p_B=0.60\times100=60\) mmHg; hence \(P=180\) mmHg and \(y_A=120/180=0.667\). Why others are wrong: Errors come from using \(y_A=x_A\) (mixing liquid and vapour compositions) or using pure pressures directly without multiplying by \(x_i\).

questiontext.text: In a \(T\)-\(x\) diagram of a binary system at fixed pressure, the horizontal tie-line at a given \(T\) intersects the liquid curve at \(x_A=0.20\) and the vapour curve at \(y_A=0.80\). If the overall composition is \(z_A=0.50\), what is the fraction of vapour (\(V\)) in the two-phase region?

generalfeedback.text: Lever rule in VLE gives \(z_A = V y_A + (1-V)x_A\). So \(0.50 = V(0.80) + (1-V)(0.20)=0.20+0.60V\Rightarrow V=(0.30/0.60)=0.50\). Why others are wrong: 0.25 and 0.75 often come from swapping segment lengths; 0.60 results from using \(z_A=Vy_A\) (ignoring liquid contribution).

questiontext.text: A binary liquid shows a minimum-boiling azeotrope at a certain pressure. Which statement is most consistent with this observation?

generalfeedback.text: Minimum-boiling azeotropes are associated with higher-than-ideal vapour pressures (positive deviations), producing a boiling point lower than either pure component at that pressure. Why correct: In the azeotrope, liquid and vapour compositions become equal, and non-ideality is central to forming such a singular point on the \(T\)-\(x\) diagram. Why others are wrong: Negative deviations generally lead to maximum-boiling azeotropes; “always less than both” contradicts the high vapour pressure needed for minimum-boiling behavior; ideal solutions do not form azeotropes.

answer.text: The solution shows negative deviation from Raoult’s law.
The solution shows positive deviation from Raoult’s law.
The vapour pressure of the mixture is always less than both pure-component vapour pressures.
The mixture must be ideal at all compositions.

questiontext.text: A partially miscible binary liquid system exhibits an upper critical solution temperature (UCST). Which behaviour is correct?

generalfeedback.text: UCST means that miscibility increases with temperature, and above the UCST only one liquid phase exists for all compositions. Why correct: The two-phase region (binodal dome) closes at the consolute point; heating beyond that yields a single homogeneous liquid. Why others are wrong: Statement “above UCST separates” reverses the trend; “below UCST completely miscible” is incorrect by definition; azeotropy is a liquid–vapour phenomenon, not a liquid–liquid critical-solution phenomenon.

answer.text: Above UCST the system separates into two liquid phases.
Below UCST the system is completely miscible at all compositions.
Above UCST the system becomes completely miscible at all compositions.
UCST implies the system forms an azeotrope.

questiontext.text: In a simple binary eutectic system with complete immiscibility in solid state, a liquid of eutectic composition is cooled slowly through the eutectic temperature. The first solid(s) that appear at the eutectic temperature are:

generalfeedback.text: At the eutectic point, the invariant equilibrium involves liquid + two solid phases in coexistence; cooling through the eutectic temperature causes the liquid to transform into two solids together. Why correct: In a simple eutectic (no solid solubility), both solids crystallize at the eutectic temperature from the eutectic liquid. Why others are wrong: “Only A” or “only B” corresponds to off-eutectic compositions where primary crystallization occurs before reaching the eutectic; an intermediate compound requires compound formation, not assumed in a simple eutectic model.

answer.text: Only solid A
Only solid B
A mixture of solid A and solid B simultaneously
An intermediate compound AB

questiontext.text: A one-component system is at \(P=1\) atm. The CO\(_2\) phase diagram is known to have a triple point near 5.1 atm. What phase transition is feasible at 1 atm upon heating solid CO\(_2\)?

generalfeedback.text: Since the triple point pressure of CO\(_2\) is around 5.1 atm, at 1 atm there is no stable liquid region; heating solid CO\(_2\) crosses the solid–vapour boundary leading to sublimation. Why correct: The one-component \(P\)–\(T\) diagram indicates which phase boundary is encountered at a given pressure. Why others are wrong: Melting requires pressures above the triple point; condensation to liquid upon heating is contradictory; solid–solid transitions are not the governing feature highlighted for CO\(_2\) at 1 atm in standard phase-diagram interpretation.

answer.text: Melting to liquid, then boiling
Sublimation directly to vapour
Condensation to liquid
Solid–solid transition to a denser allotrope, then melting

questiontext.text: A binary mixture is distilled at constant pressure and is found to approach a constant boiling composition beyond which further separation by fractional distillation is not possible. This limitation is best explained by:

generalfeedback.text: In an azeotrope, the equilibrium vapour composition equals the liquid composition at that pressure, producing constant-boiling behaviour and limiting separation by ordinary fractional distillation. Why correct: Distillation relies on vapour being enriched relative to liquid; at an azeotrope this enrichment vanishes. Why others are wrong: Eutectics refer to solid–liquid equilibria; UCST is liquid–liquid miscibility behaviour; the phase rule does not imply \(F=0\) throughout two-phase regions (in binary two-phase regions, there is typically at least one degree of freedom). (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/c8559d0f-a3ee-4a44-bd03-d515f36af380/physical_unit_07.txt)

answer.text: Formation of a eutectic point
Equality of liquid and vapour compositions at an azeotrope
Existence of UCST in the liquid–liquid diagram
The phase rule predicting \(F=0\) for all two-phase regions
